comment.body: I very much like the keyslot idea. Would it be sensible to drive it further by setting up an array _defining_ the hybrid scheme? Something like `[Alg_Name0, Alg_Name1, Alg_Name2, ...]` (or IDs) and call in loop(s) `oqs_qs_kem_encaps_keyslot` or `oqs_evp_kem_encaps_keyslot` (or ...decaps... below) as appropriate? Just an idea, surely not essential for this PR.

pull_request.title: Hybrid KEM support
pull_request.body:
Hybrid KEM support for the oqs-provider (#3):
- Combines OQS KEMs with OpenSSL EC-kex
- Uses EVP API for OpenSSL EC-kex
- Wraps hybrid KEM in OpenSSL3 KEM-API
- Extends oqsx.h structures to accomodate KEM and KEX contexts
- Refactoring to use preprocessor for hybrid combinations
- Refactors oqs_test_groups: test iterates over all tls-groups in the oqs-provider
- OQS/ECP and OQS/ECX hybrids
- Updated fragments
- Added generate-extras.yml with `nid_ecx_hybrid` code points. They are added by generate.py to the generate.yml elements fetched from the OSSL111 repo.
- NIST-CAT5/X448 hybrids not enabled (see https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/issues/296)
- Unrelated: A new run of generate.py also updated the Rainbow OIDs.

comment.body: Is there really no other way to reference to classic crypto than by NID? I thought one of the goals of OSSL3 was to get rid of them (?). But again, this is a nitpick and surely asking too much in this context.

comment.body: Here'd be another place where iterating the "algorithm array" proposed above would permit creating arbitrary hybrid schemes. Again, not required for this PR.

comment.body: Can the KEM-KEYTYPES not be handled by the same code? To me this is an indication that the "logical merge"/refactoring was successful.

comment.body: This naming may be confusing ("is privkey_ptr just a pointer to privkey? why have both?"): If I get it right, "privkey_ptr" rather is "component_privkey" and "privkey" _is_ the true (possibly hybrid/composite) private key (?). Same with pubkey(s).

comment.body: Yes this would be useful, something more generic like this was also my initial idea when adding the keyslots. The main obstacle right now is that secret and ciphertext lengths are attached to source-specific structs (i.e. OQS_KEM/OQS_SIG vs the custom structs I've added for EVP). If this can be unified (e.g.  by queries to the new provider API), your suggested approach should be doable.

pull_request.title: Hybrid KEM support
pull_request.body:
Hybrid KEM support for the oqs-provider (#3):
- Combines OQS KEMs with OpenSSL EC-kex
- Uses EVP API for OpenSSL EC-kex

- Unrelated: A new run of generate.py also updated the Rainbow OIDs.

comment.body:
I was careful to not use any internal or deprecated OSSL API, but the API used should still be backward compatible with OSSL111. Will still have to dig to the new provider API to see if there is another way, e.g. with strings or OIDs.
Defining the key-, secret-, and ciphertext-sizes is also not optimal yet. I'd prefer to be able to query them via some provider API than defining them here.

comment.body: I agree. Similarly as in the comment above, I'd ideally like to combine this with a more uniform API to query key-, secret-, and ciphertext-sizes.

comment.body:
The first reason for the distinction is that the init-logic of ECP and ECX curves is still different. The second reason for the two key types is to give an indication to the code, which EC-family should be used for strength-matching.
At least the first point would be nice to be addressed by revisiting the use of new provider API.

comment.body: Yes, correct, the privkey_ptr elements point to locations in the main key. I will rename them as you suggest. The reason for the "privkey_ptr"/"component_privkey" is that the KEM code can access them using their "keyslot", without having to deal with any offsets in the main "privkey"

> revisiting the use of new provider API

what do you mean by this? Are we not running on upstream master? How can there be something even more new?
